subject: Education
Developmental and Educational Psychology

Journal.Title: Journal of applied research in intellectual disabilities : JARID

Article.ArticleTitle: An exploration of lifestyle/obesity programmes for adults with intellectual disabilities through a realist lens: Impact of a 'context, mechanism and outcome' evaluation.

AbstractText: Obesity is higher in people with intellectual disabilities.

There are two aims of this explorative paper. Firstly, using a realist lens, to go beyond 'what works' and examine the 'context, mechanisms and outcomes' (CMO) of lifestyle/obesity programmes for this population. Second, using a logic model framework to inform how these programmes could be implemented within practice.
We explored six-review papers and the individual lifestyle/obesity programmes that these papers reviewed using the CMO framework.

There were few theoretically underpinned, multi-component programmes that were effective in the short to long-term and many failed to explore the 'context and mechanisms'. We developed a logic model and engaged in two co-production workshops to refine this model.

Using a realist approach, programmes need to be underpinned by both individual and systems change theories, be multi-component, have a closer understanding of the interplay of the 'context and mechanisms', and co-designed using a logic model framework.

entry.dc:title: An exploration of lifestyle/obesity programmes for adults with intellectual disabilities through a realist lens: Impact of a ‘context, mechanism and outcome’ evaluation
entry.dc:creator: Taggart L.
entry.prism:publicationName: Journal of Applied Research in Intellectual Disabilities

clean.title: An exploration of lifestyle/obesity programmes for adults with intellectual disabilities through a realist lens: Impact of a 'context, mechanism and outcome' evaluation.

affiliation.name: Institute of Nursing & Health Research, Ulster University, Co Antrim, UK.
Faculty of Health & Wellbeing, University of Central Lancashire (UCLan), Preston, UK.
Faculty of Health & Wellbeing, University of Central Lancashire (UCLan), Preston, UK.
Division of Psychiatry, University College London, London, UK.

clean.abstract: ['Obesity is higher in people with intellectual disabilities.', "There are two aims of this explorative paper. Firstly, using a realist lens, to go beyond 'what works' and examine the 'context, mechanisms and outcomes' (CMO) of lifestyle/obesity programmes for this population. Second, using a logic model framework to inform how these programmes could be implemented within practice.", 'We explored six-review papers and the individual lifestyle/obesity programmes that these papers reviewed using the CMO framework.', "There were few theoretically underpinned, multi-component programmes that were effective in the short to long-term and many failed to explore the 'context and mechanisms'. We developed a logic model and engaged in two co-production workshops to refine this model.", "Using a realist approach, programmes need to be underpinned by both individual and systems change theories, be multi-component, have a closer understanding of the interplay of the 'context and mechanisms', and co-designed using a logic model framework."]

location.candidate_institute: Institute of Nursing & Health Research, Ulster University, Co Antrim, UK.
